title: 00-Hello
text:
What is it?

R Markdown, next generation

All based on knitr to execute R code


Analyze. Share. Reproduce. You have a story to tell with data—tell it with Quarto.



In this course: RStudio!
Download R: https://cran.r-project.org/bin/windows/base/
Download RStudio: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/

title: 00-Hello
text:
R Markdown
markdown is a markup languange: Programming language where formatting is handled by chunk codes, tags




Format
Extension




Markdown
.md


R Markdown
.Rmd


Quarto
.qmd

title: 00-Hello
text:
Why?
Using knitr, it allows for integrating analyses, text, and graphs in a single document:

Replicability
Tydiness
Convenience

Create dynamic content with Python, R, Julia, and Observable

title: 00-Hello
text:
An example













But you are asked to change the ggplot theme!
Using a WYSIWYG:

Re-open R
Find the data again
Re-run the analysis
Plot the results with the requested changes
Save the plot
Import the plot in the document



Here.. just add + theme_light() to the code and render it again

title: 00-Hello
text:
Be tidy: Rstudio Project
Create a directory that can be re-organized in subdirectories, allowing for a conveninet managment of all the files (data, images, bibliography)
File \(\rightarrow\) New project:

knitr::include_graphics("img/project1.png")

title: 00-Hello
text:
graph = ggplot(rock, 
         aes(x = peri, 
             y = perm, size = area)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_light()
graph

title: 00-Hello
text:
graph = ggplot(rock, 
         aes(x = peri, 
             y = perm, size = area)) + 
  geom_point() + theme_light()
library(plotly)
ggplotly(graph)

Your turn!

Create a default R project for this course
Create a GitHub account (and install Git and GitHub desktop)
Add the project you have created for this course to your GitHub account
Check whether the repository is available online and make it public
Place the dataset in a subfolder named data

title: My very first quarto document
text:
This is your very first quarto document


You can organize it in sections

title: My very first quarto document
text: You can organize it in sections

title: Reporting using quarto
text:
Reproducible reports integrate the code used for data analysis with the document that presents the findings, this enabling a continuous flow between the analytical process and its interpretation.
While RMarkdown undoubtedly opened the way to this process, quarto represents the next generation, as it is even easier to use than RMarkdown and includes new features, making the reporting process more accessible.
This course provides an introduction to quarto and its basic features, along with a presentation on how to exploit it functionalities to create polished, professional outputs with embedded code chunks.
Some of the topics covered within this seminar are:

Executable code chunks
Tables & charts
Reports and papers
Presentations & so much more



All course materials are freely available on this website:

00-Hello Let’s get all set download source
01-Baby steps Formatting with markdwon, integration with github pages & layout download source
02-Code chunks How to control the executable code download source



04-PDF with LaTeX download source

Here you can download the dataset that we are going to use throughout the course, while here the file for checking whether everything works.
The source GitHub repository is available here.




Document example download .qmd
HTML presentation example download .qmd
PDF presentation example download .qmd
Basic theme download .scss
Bibliography (it is needed for compiling the example document) dowload .bib

title: 04-PDF
text:
To compile PDF files (presentations or documents), you need an installation of 






Easy mode



TinyTex
It’s convenient because it is easy to use, but it does not offer all the functionalities of 








Pro mode



MikTex
It’s a pain in the neck but it’s convenient in the long run


. . .
For this course, we can use TinyTex



Basics commands of might work in quarto as well (when compiled in PDF)
Quarto allows for using without knowing how it works (i.e., by using the same tags used for html files)
PDFs do not offer interactivity, but they do look professional
Importantly, PDFs are stable






---
title: "I can use LaTeX"
author: "Jane Doe"
format: beamer
---

## New Slide

- First element
- Second element

## Another slide

Some text in my slide! Yay!





---
[...]
format:
  beamer:
    slide-level: 2
---

# This create a section page

## This create a slide

- First element
- Second element

# New section

text:
Layout & font

Columns

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}
contents...
:::

::: {.column width="60%"}
contents...
:::

::::


Text size


\Large Large
\large large
\normalsize normal
\small small
\footnotesize footnotesize
\scriptsize script
\tiny very tiny

Large
large
normal
small
footnotesize
script
very tiny

title: 04-PDF
text:
Code Chunk


same as before! Of course it cannot be interactive.

```{r}
#| eval: true
3*2
```

[1] 6

title: 04-PDF
text:
Code annotation



library(tidyverse)
1mtcars %>%
2  ggplot( aes(mpg, hp, size = gear)) +
3  geom_point() +
4  geom_smooth(method = "lm")


1

Do something

2

Do something else

3

And else

4

Whatever




In the code: # <1>, # <2> etc
In the YAML
[...]
code-annotations: below

title: 04-PDF
text:
External Figures


There’s a peacock in Figure 1

```{r}
#| out-width: 70%
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap: "A peacock"
#| label: fig-pea

knitr::include_graphics("img/peacock.png")
```







Figure 1: A peacock








There's a peacock in @fig-pea1

```{r}
#| eval: false
#| out-width: 70%
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap: "A peacock"
#| label: fig-pea1

knitr::include_graphics("img/peacock.png")
```

title: 04-PDF
text:
Plots


A kickass plot in Figure 2

```{r}
#| out-width: 70%
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap: "What a plot"
#| label: fig-plot
#| 
ggplot(mtcars, aes(hp, mpg, color = factor(am))) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(formula = y ~ x, method = "loess") +
  theme(legend.position = 'bottom')
```







Figure 2: What a plot








A kickass plot in @fig-plot1

```{r}
#| eval: false
#| out-width: 70%
#| fig-align: center
#| fig-cap: "What a plot"
#| label: fig-plot1
#| 
ggplot(mtcars, aes(hp, mpg, color = factor(am))) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(formula = y ~ x, method = "loess") +
  theme(legend.position = 'bottom')
```

title: 00-Hello
text:
To explore the potentials of integrating code chunks, analyses, and results in one unique document, we need to work with a real dataset:

Download dataset from the course website

Dataset details:

anxiety: Anxiety score — higher scores indicate higher levels of anxiety
flexibility: Cognitive flexibility score — higher scores indicate greater flexibility
mindfulness: Whether the person practices mindfulness daily, no vs. yes
activity: Type of sport activity practiced, pilates, altro, yoga
